5.learning_goal: Relational Databases Basics: In this unit, students will learn why relational databases exist, how DBMS software organizes data into well-designed tables with primary and foreign keys, and how to model real-world scenarios (like apps, stores, and events) into schemas that correctly represent relationships and support meaningful queries.

chapters.title: Why We Use Relational Databases
chapters.learning_goals: Understand what databases are, why they exist, and how they differ from files and in-memory data. Learn to recognize when real-world data—like cafe orders or music app information—belongs in relational tables with rows, columns, and relationships.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Why Databases Exist
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain what a database is and what problems it solves; Distinguish databases from files and in-memory data; Identify data in real applications that belongs in a database.

lessons.title: What Is a Relational Database
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define relational databases as tables connected by relationships; Describe rows, columns, and tables using concrete examples; Explain why relationships matter for real-world data.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Cafe data vs. database
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish when data should live in a database versus in files or in memory by analyzing a small cafe story. Output: A completed written/typed worksheet where each piece of cafe data is classified as “file”, “in-memory”, or “database” with short justifications.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Spot the tables in a music app
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify real-world data in a music app scenario that belongs in relational tables and describe them in terms of rows and columns. Output: A simple text/table document listing proposed tables (e.g., Songs, Artists, Playlists) with example columns and a few example rows for each.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Foundations of Databases and DBMS
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how relational databases organize data into tables of rows and columns, and understand what a DBMS is, how it differs from a database, and how it processes queries. Practice identifying DBMSs and applications, and redesigning messy “all-in-one” tables into cleaner, well-structured schemas.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: DBMS: The Software Behind the Data
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define DBMS and distinguish it from a database; Name common relational DBMSs (e.g., SQLite, PostgreSQL); Explain at a high level how a DBMS stores data and executes queries.

lessons.title: Tables, Rows, Columns
lessons.learning_outcomes: Describe how relational databases organize data using tables; Explain the role of rows and columns in storing structured data; Identify when a table mixes multiple real-world concepts incorrectly.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: DBMS detective
lessons.learning_outcomes: Differentiate between a database and a DBMS and match real-world tools (e.g., PostgreSQL) to their role in storing and querying data. Output: A completed matching/short-answer sheet where each description is labeled as “DBMS”, “database”, or “application”, plus a short paragraph explaining how a DBMS processes a query.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Fix the messy table
lessons.learning_outcomes: Analyze a poorly designed “all-in-one” table and decide how to split it into better tables with clear rows and columns. Output: A redesigned set of 2–3 tables written out in text form, each with a table name, column names, and a brief note on what each row represents.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Designing Relational Database Schemas
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to design clear relational schemas from real-world scenarios by identifying entities, choosing stable primary keys, and assigning attributes to avoid duplication and confusion. Practice applying these concepts through guided examples and Q&A to build confidence in basic database design.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Primary Keys
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define a primary key as a column that uniquely identifies a row; Explain why tables need stable values that other tables can reference; Select an appropriate primary key based on real-world data.

lessons.title: Designing a Schema
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define schema as the set of tables and columns in a database; Design tables from a short real-world story (entities → tables); Assign attributes to tables to avoid duplication and confusion.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Choosing primary keys for a library
lessons.learning_outcomes: Select appropriate primary keys for different tables in a small library scenario and justify why they uniquely and stably identify rows. Output: A short document listing tables (e.g., Books, Members, Loans) with chosen primary key columns and one-sentence justifications for each choice.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Schema design for an event planner
lessons.learning_outcomes: Design a simple relational schema from a story about planning events, turning entities into tables and assigning attributes to avoid duplication. Output: A schema sketch listing tables (e.g., Events, Venues, Guests), their columns, and a brief explanation of how this design reduces confusion and repeated data.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Modeling Relationships with Foreign Keys
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to identify one-to-many and many-to-many relationships, model them using primary and foreign keys, and explain how these relationships enable JOIN queries to answer real-world questions in systems like online stores and course platforms.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Foreign Keys
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define foreign keys and how they reference primary keys; Model a one-to-many relationship using PK and FK; Explain how foreign keys enable JOIN queries.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Foreign keys in an online store - Part 1
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify one-to-many relationships in an online store story and decide which columns should be foreign keys referencing which primary keys. Output: A relationship map listing tables (e.g., Customers, Orders, OrderItems) with arrows showing which foreign keys reference which primary keys.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Foreign keys in an online store - Part 2
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain how the defined foreign keys would enable JOIN queries to answer real questions like “What did this customer order?”. Output: A set of written example questions plus, for each, a plain-language description of which tables would be joined and via which foreign key–primary key pairs.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Relationship quiz for a course platform
lessons.learning_outcomes: Classify relationships (one-to-many, many-to-many) in a course platform scenario and assign foreign keys to model them correctly. Output: A completed quiz-style sheet where each pair of entities (e.g., Students–Courses, Instructors–Courses, Lessons–Courses) is labeled with the relationship type and proposed foreign key placement.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

6.learning_goal: Foundations of SQL Queries: In this unit, students will learn to think declaratively in SQL by writing and reading basic SELECT queries, intentionally choosing and aliasing columns, and applying WHERE filters with AND/OR to retrieve and explain targeted result sets from relational databases.

chapters.title: Getting Started with SQL Queries
chapters.learning_goals: Learn what SQL is, how it interfaces with relational databases, and how to write basic SELECT statements. Practice retrieving specific columns, using column aliases, and clearly describing what simple queries ask the database to do.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Hello, SQL!
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define SQL and describe what kind of language it is (declarative); Explain what is the role of SQL vs DMBS; Recognize SQL as the interface for querying relational databases; Get to know the basic syntax and structure of SQL using a simple SELET query.

lessons.title: More about SELECT
lessons.learning_outcomes: Write basic queries that retrieve specific columns from a table; Learn how to get only specific columns and how to alias columns.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe menu explorer
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use basic SELECT queries to retrieve specific columns from a single table and describe in words what the query is asking the database to do. Output: A set of query results that list selected details (like drink names and prices) from a fictional cafe menu table.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Music library columns and aliases
lessons.learning_outcomes: Write SELECT queries that choose only needed columns and apply clear column aliases to improve readability of query results. Output: A neatly formatted result set showing song, artist, and duration with user-friendly column names from a fictional music library table.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Thinking in SQL
chapters.learning_goals: In this chapter, students will learn to read and predict SQL query results, debug simple queries, and clearly explain what each row in a result set represents. They will also deepen their understanding of SQL as a declarative language by contrasting it with procedural languages, articulating the “what, not how” mindset, and breaking down the structure of SQL statements.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Reading Query Results
lessons.learning_outcomes: Predict query results by reading SQL statements; Explain what each row in a result set represents; Debug simple queries.

lessons.title: SQL: How Queries Are Written
lessons.learning_outcomes: Describe SQL as a declarative query language; Explain the structure of a SQL statement; Distinguish SQL from procedural languages like Python.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Query result detective
lessons.learning_outcomes: Correctly predict and explain the result sets of given SQL queries by reasoning about rows, columns, and conditions. Output: A written set of predicted tables and explanations for what each query will return and why.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Declarative vs procedural thinking
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish declarative SQL from procedural languages by matching concepts, ordering parts of a SQL statement, and explaining how “what, not how” applies to queries. Output: Completed matching, ordering, and short-answer explanations that break down the structure and nature of SQL queries.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Purposeful Selecting and Filtering
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to write focused SELECT queries that choose specific columns, apply clear aliases, and use WHERE clauses with comparison operators to filter data for realistic scenarios. Build confidence debugging query logic while creating practical views like bookstore inventories and movie rental filters.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Picking Columns on Purpose
lessons.learning_outcomes: Write SELECT queries with specific columns; Use column aliases to rename output; Explain how selected columns relate to the schema.

lessons.title: Filtering with WHERE
lessons.learning_outcomes: Write WHERE clauses using comparison operators; Filter results based on realistic conditions; Debug incorrect filtering logic.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Bookstore inventory view
lessons.learning_outcomes: Write SELECT queries that intentionally pick specific columns from a bookstore inventory schema and use aliases to create a clear “manager view” of the data. Output: A set of query results showing book titles, authors, prices, and stock levels with readable column headings.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Movie rental filter
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use WHERE clauses with comparison operators to filter a movie rentals table for realistic conditions and debug incorrect filters by adjusting the logic. Output: Several filtered result sets showing only movies that match criteria like minimum rating, price range, or availability.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Mastering AND/OR Filters
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to correctly use AND, OR, and parentheses in SQL WHERE clauses to combine multiple conditions, and to explain in plain language which records are included or excluded. Practice designing and testing filters in realistic scenarios (customers and events) to confidently build and interpret complex query logic.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: AND vs OR
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish AND from OR using concrete examples; Combine multiple conditions correctly; Explain filter logic in plain language.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Online store customer filter - Part 1
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply AND and OR in simple WHERE clauses and explain in plain language which customers will be included or excluded by each condition. Output: Query results that list customers matching straightforward combined conditions (such as location and signup date).

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Online store customer filter - Part 2
lessons.learning_outcomes: Combine multiple AND/OR conditions with parentheses to control filter logic and verify the results by checking which rows should logically appear. Output: Refined query results showing different customer segments based on complex combinations of purchase behavior and location.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Event ticket finder
lessons.learning_outcomes: Design and test filters using AND and OR to help users find events that match multiple possible criteria (date ranges, price limits, and categories). Output: A set of queries and result tables that surface only events matching user-like search conditions.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

7.learning_goal: Intermediate SQL Filtering and Joins: In this unit, students will learn to precisely filter and sort data using IN, BETWEEN, NULL conditions, ORDER BY, and LIMIT; write JOIN queries across multiple tables from schemas and ER diagrams; and explain when and why to use SQLite versus server-based databases, applying these skills in realistic querying and database-choice scenarios and demonstrating mastery in a weekly assessment.

chapters.title: Filtering Data with IN, BETWEEN, and NULL
chapters.learning_goals: In this chapter, students will learn to filter data using IN and BETWEEN, correctly handle NULL values with IS NULL and IS NOT NULL, and choose the clearest filtering approach for a given task. Through practical scenarios (like cafe orders and music libraries), they will write SQL queries that return precise, targeted subsets of data while understanding how missing values affect results.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: IN and BETWEEN
lessons.learning_outcomes: Filter using IN for multiple values; Filter using BETWEEN for ranges; Choose the clearest filtering approach.

lessons.title: NULL Means Missing
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define NULL and distinguish it from empty values; Write IS NULL and IS NOT NULL conditions; Predict how NULL affects query results.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe orders filter
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply IN, BETWEEN, IS NULL, and IS NOT NULL to filter a cafe’s orders table for specific products, price ranges, and missing data. Output: A set of SQL queries that return targeted subsets of orders (e.g., certain drinks, price ranges, and orders with missing customer info).

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Music library search
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use IN and BETWEEN to filter songs by genre and duration while correctly handling NULL values in optional fields like album or release year. Output: A set of SQL queries that produce filtered song lists based on multiple genres, time ranges, and presence/absence of metadata.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Controlling and Refining Query Results
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to sort, limit, and combine SQL query results using ORDER BY, LIMIT, and WHERE so that outputs match specific business questions. Practice applying these tools in realistic scenarios like bookstore catalogs and movie recommendations while clearly distinguishing filtering from sorting.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Sorting Results
lessons.learning_outcomes: Sort query results using ORDER BY; Choose meaningful sorting directions; Explain the difference between filtering and sorting.

lessons.title: Limiting Output
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use LIMIT to control result size; Combine WHERE, ORDER BY, and LIMIT; Validate that results match the question asked.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Bookstore catalog sorting
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use ORDER BY with different sort directions to organize a bookstore’s inventory and clearly separate sorting from filtering. Output: A collection of SQL queries that display books ordered by price, title, and publication date according to different business questions.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Movie recommendations limit
lessons.learning_outcomes: Combine WHERE, ORDER BY, and LIMIT to produce concise, ranked movie recommendation lists that match a specific request. Output: A set of SQL queries that return the top N movies by rating, popularity, or release date, constrained to relevant filters like genre or year.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Joining Data Across Tables
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how and why data is split into multiple tables, how to read ER diagrams to find join paths, and how to write practical SQL JOIN queries that combine related tables into clear, meaningful reports.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: JOIN: Bringing Tables Together
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain why data is split across tables; Identify join keys using PK and FK; Write a basic JOIN query.

lessons.title: From Diagram to Query
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify join paths from ER diagrams; Write JOIN queries across two tables; Modify queries with filtering and sorting.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Online store orders join
lessons.learning_outcomes: Write basic JOIN queries using primary and foreign keys to combine customers, orders, and products into a single result set. Output: SQL queries that produce a detailed order report showing customer names, product details, and order totals from multiple tables.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Library loans from diagram
lessons.learning_outcomes: Translate an ER diagram of a library system into JOIN queries that connect members, books, and loans with optional filtering and sorting. Output: SQL queries that list which members borrowed which books, when they borrowed them, and optionally order results by due date or member name.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Choosing SQLite for Real-World Applications
chapters.learning_goals: Learn what SQLite is, how it compares to server-based databases, and when it is the right tool for a given problem. Practice evaluating real-world scenarios and use cases to decide whether SQLite or a server DBMS is the better choice, and clearly justify that decision.
